variant.question: A pilot sees a very high oil temperature indication and decides to disconnect IDG 1\. Which of the following will happen?

options.text: IDG 1 will continue to provide electricity even when disconnected from the AC bus bar.
The generator will stop providing electricity, and can only be reconnected on the ground.
The IDG will stop providing electricity, but can be re-connected in flight after a sufficient cooling period.
IDG 1 will continue to provide electricity even when disconnected from the AC bus bar, but can be re-connected in flight after a sufficient cooling period.

variant.question: What is the worst case scenario if thermal runaway occurs?

options.text: Fire.
Engine failure.
Overcurrent in the electrical system.
Total loss of electrical power.

variant.question: Which of these statements about frequency are correct/incorrect?
firstCorrectStatements: Frequency is defined as a number of cycles per unit of time.
firstIncorrectStatements: Frequency is defined as a number of waves per unit of time.
secondCorrectStatements: The SI unit for frequency is Hertz (Hz).
secondIncorrectStatements: The SI unit for frequency is revolutions per minute (RPM).

variant.question:
Which of the following formulas describes how the torque of an electrical motor is determined by the supplied voltage and current and the resulting RPM.

T = Torque, U = Voltage, H = RPM, I = Current.

options.text: T = U × I
T = U × H × I
T = (U × I) / H
T = U × H / I

variant.question: On an aircraft with two main generators, if one generator fails...

options.text: the busbar will be switched to another busbar.
the components fed by that busbar will lose power and become unusable.
the busbar is isolated completely, but its output components are switched to another busbar.
the busbar is switched to an alternate power source so that its electrical components will be supplied with power.

variant.question: An AC generator provides a constant output voltage, when the electrical load increases. What will the voltage regulator do?

options.text: Change the direction of the excitation current.
Increase the excitation current.
Decrease the excitation current.
Nothing, the voltage will not need to change.

variant.question: In an aircraft\`s electrical distribution system the "hot bus-bar" is..

options.text: directly connected to the battery.
a means of providing an alternative current.
automatically connected to the battery if generators have failed.
kept in operating conditions by an electrical resistance in the case of energy failure.

variant.question: The main purpose of a Constant Speed Drive unit is to..

options.text: maintain a constant frequency.
achieve reactive load sharing.
provide voltage regulation.
mechanically protect the alternator drive shaft during coupling.

variant.question: A unit that converts DC into AC is..

options.text: an inverter.
a thermistor.
a transformer rectifier unit.
an AC generator.

variant.question: In flight, if the Constant Speed Drive (CSD) temperature indicator is in the red arc the:

options.text:
| pilot must disconnect it, and the generator is not available for the rest of flight. |
| ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ |

| pilot can disconnect it to allow it to cool and use it again. |
| ------------------------------------------------------------- |

| pilot has to throttle back. |
| --------------------------- |

| pilot must disconnect it and manually control the alternator. |
| ------------------------------------------------------------- |

variant.question: Why would you place a lithium ion battery in a metal vented case?

options.text: To contain a thermal runaway.
To avoid leaking of its liquid coolant.
To provide a protective casing.
To prevent the release of toxic fumes.

variant.question:
Refer to figure.   
The annex shows the layout of an electrical system for a twin-engined aeroplane. What is the purpose of the TRUs?

options.text: To convert AC power into DC power at a different (usually lower) voltage.
To convert DC power into AC power at a different (usually higher) voltage.
To separate the DC systems (powered by the generators) from the AC systems (powered by the batteries).
To separate the AC systems (powered by the generators) from the DC systems (powered by the batteries).

variant.question: Given a wire fed with alternating current and a second wire parallel to, but remote from it. The result will be:

options.text: The first wire will radiate electro-magnetic waves into space and direct current will be induced in the second wire.
The first wire will radiate electro-magnetic waves into space and the second wire will double the transmission power of the first one.
The first wire will radiate electro-magnetic waves into space and alternating current will be induced in the second wire.
The first wire will radiate electro-magnetic waves into space but the transmitted energy will be completely absorbed by the second wire.

variant.question: In a modern aircraft with 3 AC generators (two turbine engines and an APU), the generators all fail, and only battery power remains. How would the essential AC bus be powered?

options.text: It would not be powered as there are no AC sources remaining.
It contains its own battery which directly provides AC power in case of an outage.
It is powered by the main battery via an inverter, to keep essential AC consumers running in the event of a total generation failure.
It is directly connected to the main battery to power essential aircraft controls and components.

variant.question: When the AC generators are connected in parallel, the reactive loads are balanced by means of the..

options.text: load controller.
frequency controller.
excitation current.
engine RPM.

variant.question: A starter-generator is an electrical generator that…

options.text: creates a high energy impulse for the igniters during engine start.
generates electric power for the engine starter motor.
uses an electric starter motor for start-up of its rotor.
performs as an electric motor during engine start.

variant.question: When climbing out at a low altitude in an aircraft fitted with an Split Bus Bar System, the Voltage reading from GEN 1 (IDG) suddenly spikes up to 1000V which engages a caution announciator. What is the pilot’s immediate action?

options.text: Nothing, the system is protected by circuit breakers and a GCU which does not need pilot input.
Disconnect the generator by deactivating the Exciter Control Relay Field and switching to Emergency Power by turning on the APU.
Observe the additional engine parameters and get the appropriate checklist.
Restart the malfuctioning IDG by disconnecting and reconnecting it to the Split Bus Bar system.

variant.question: When the "disconnect" switch is activated on the electrical panel, it disconnects..

options.text: Shaft from the oil system
IDG from gearbox
Generator from the CSD
IFD from breaker

variant.question: The flight crew has to be notified if a large amount of lithium batteries are being carried in the hold as...

options.text: they explode when cabin pressure is high due to pressure differential.
they produce heat, so firefighters have to be present during loading and unloading.
they freeze, causing their metal case to crack.
they are prone to thermal runaway if they overheat.

variant.question: What is a Transformer Rectifier Unit (TRU) used for?

options.text: To convert from DC to AC, usually to a lower voltage.
To convert from AC to DC, usually to a lower voltage.
To convert from AC to DC, usually to a higher voltage.
To convert from DC to AC, usually to a higher voltage.

variant.question: An AC generator's frequency is measured using which unit, and can be described as what?

options.text: Cycles (C), the number of repetitions per minute.
Hertz (Hz), the number of oscillations per second.
Watts (W), the rate of electron flow.
Volts (V), electricity produced per minute.

variant.question: What is likely to cause a short circuit?

options.text: Corrosion of the aircraft's metal skin.
Loose electrical bonding cables.
Poor insulation of electric wires.
Missing static dischargers.

variant.question: In an AC circuit with a capacitor, voltage is kept the same, but the AC frequency is increased. What will happen to the current?

options.text: Current decreases.
current increases.
Current remains the same.
Current reduces down to a value of zero.

variant.question:
Refer to figure.

In the diagram, the component 4 is a:

options.text: static inverter.
battery.
TRU.
contactor.

variant.question: What is the purpose of separate shielding on each electrical wire within a bundle of cables?

options.text: To physically strengthen the bundle of wires.
To eliminate electromagnetic induction interfering with other wires in the bundle.
To allow wires to be labelled for quicker maintenance.
To properly insulate each wire from the others in the bundle.

variant.question: What will happen if a bus bar has a short circuit? The affected bus...

options.text: is isolated and consumers lost.
is isolated and consumers fed by another generator.
is transferred to another busbar.
is transferred to another generator.

variant.question: On aircraft with (1)\_\_\_ generators as the primary source of electrical power, Transformer Rectifier Units (TRUs) are used to obtain (2)\_\_\_ electrical power.
Which of the following gives the correct definition and SI unit for electrical power (P)?

options.text: Electrical power is energy multiplied by time (t) (P = Energy x t). It is measured in watts (W).
Electrical power is energy is divided by time (t) (P = Energy/t). It is measured in watts (W).
Electrical power is current (I) divided by voltage (V) (P = I/V). It is measured in amperes (A).
Electrical power is voltage (V) divided by current (I) (P = V/I). It is measured in watts (W).

variant.question: You are flying a twin-engined aircraft with an AC electrical system fed by two engine driven generators when one generator has a complete failure. Which of the following statements is correct in reference to the subsequent power distribution.
firstCorrectStatements: In an AC electrical system with a split-bus design, the load from the failed generator is automatically taken over by the remaining generator through the automatic AC bus-transfer function.
firstIncorrectStatements: In an AC electrical system with a split-bus design, the load from the failed generator is manually taken over by the remaining generator through the manual AC bus-transfer function.
secondCorrectStatements: In an AC electrical system with a parallel bus design, the load from the failed generator is not directly taken over by the aircraft's battery providing DC electrical power to the bus.
secondIncorrectStatements: In an AC electrical system with a parallel bus design, the load from the failed generator is directly taken over by the aircraft's battery providing DC electrical power to the bus.

variant.question: If an electrical circuit overload occurs but is NOT detected, what might occur?

options.text: The bypass line will be activated.
The fuse may blow.
The electrical line could overheat and cause a fire.
The generators will overheat and fail.

variant.question: The function of a constant speed drive is to ensure..

options.text: an equal AC voltage output from all generators.
that the generator produces a constant frequency.
that the starter-motor maintains a constant RPM irrespective of engine acceleration/deceleration.
that the output voltage remains constant irrespective of generator RPM.

variant.question: One indication of inadequate bonding of aircraft components may be:

options.text: interference on the VOR receiver.
static noise on the radio.
heavy corrosion on the fuselage skin mountings.
a circuit breaker popping out.

variant.question: In a DC electric motor with stator and rotor coils in series, an armature runaway will cause the current in the armature to...

options.text: decrease, but because the current in the stator coil increases, the torque will stay the same.
increase, but because the current in the stator coil decreases, the torque will stay the same.
decrease, and because the current in the stator coil also decreases, the torque will decrease.
increase, and because the current in the stator coil also increases, the torque will increase.

variant.question: In the event of a complete failure of all electrical generators, with battery backups taking over, which of the following should be a main concern?

options.text: Batteries will only last for a limited amount of time.
Batteries don't have a high enough voltage to run all aircraft systems
No concern.
Batteries could begin thermal runaway under heavy load.

variant.question: In a DC (Direct Current) circuit, what will happen if the current gets too high and is not detected?

options.text: The circuit breaker will trip, disconnecting the generator from its drive unit.
The increased magnetic field will interfere with other circuits nearby.
The wire will overheat and could cause a fire.
The voltage will subsequently increase, and could blow a fuse.

variant.question: In a modern transport aircraft, in the event of a total AC generator failure, a static inverter converts (1) \_\_\_\_\_ from the batteries to (2) \_\_\_\_\_ for essential AC services.
What is usually used to lubricate Integrated Drive Generators (IDGs)?

options.text: Ram air
Fuel
Hydraulic fluid
Internal oil

variant.question: In an aircraft without a dedicated battery charging system, how are batteries charged?

options.text: By the rotary converter.
By the static inverter.
By the transformer unit.
By the transformer rectifier unit (TRU).

variant.question: Which of the following statements is correct?

options.text: Overcurrent is normal.
Any overcurrent is abnormal.
Protective devices must trip as soon as a overcurrent is detected.
Short term overcurrent is normal.

variant.question: On a modern brushless three-phase AC generator, the current that provides the field excitation to the rotor...

options.text: comes from a permanent magnet generator installed on the same shaft as the main generator.
is DC and is fed directly to the field windings of the rotor poles through contacts and slip rings.
comes from an additional, smaller DC generator installed on the end of the alternator.
is AC and is being fed directly to the field windings to the rotor poles through contacts and slip rings.

variant.question: Which of the following is the best way to prevent lithium ion batteries from becoming a fire hazard?

options.text: Make sure the battery is being continuously charged during flight.
House the battery in a vented metal casing.
Install a fuse on the positive pole of the battery.
Place a halon fire extinguisher in the compartment with the battery.

variant.question: In a multi-cell lithium battery, one cell sets on fire. Which of the following is likely to happen?

options.text: The fire will be contained within the battery by the casing, so no danger exists.
The fire will spread to other cells within the battery.
The casing around the battery will prevent the fire damaging the other cells.
The pilot will be able to stop the fire manually.

variant.question: Which statement about the storage capacity of a battery is correct?

options.text: 5 Ah means that the battery will deliver 5 amperes for 1 hour.
20 Ah means that the battery will deliver 20 amperes for 10 hours.
20 Ah means that the battery will deliver 10 amperes for 20 hours.
5 Ah means that the battery will deliver 10 amperes for 10 minutes.

variant.question: A generator has a failure. What happens to its bus?

options.text: It is isolated and the consumers are no longer supplied.
It is isolated but the consumers are transferred to another source.
It is transferred to another bus and the generator is disconnected from its drive.
It is transferred to another source and the generator is disconnected from its bus.

variant.question: You are flying an aircraft in which all the generators have failed, but you still have battery power. What should be considered?

options.text: All electrical components will become unusable for the remainder of the flight.
The most important instrument to be monitored now is the temperature of the batteries to avoid any thermal runaway.
There are no special considerations since all components previously powered by the generators will receive power from the batteries automatically.
The batteries have a limited charge, so electrical components will not be able to operate indefinitely.

variant.question: What is the SI unit of measurement for power?

options.text: W
J
Pa
N

variant.question: What may lead to generation of excess heat and potentially a fire in a circuit?

options.text: Overvoltage
Overcurrent
Overpressure
Undervoltage

variant.question: When the engine fire shut-off handle is pulled, what is the effect on the AC generator?

options.text: The exciter control relay opens.
The exciter control relay, the generator breaker, and the tie breaker open.
Only the generator breaker opens.
The exciter control relay and the generator breaker open.

variant.question: What is a bus bar?

options.text: A device to permit the use of multiple switches in one circuit.
A device used to stabilise electrical output.
A device to distribute electrical power.
A device used to convert AC to DC.

variant.question: Which of the following must be considered if all generators fail in flight, and only battery power remains?

options.text: Most of the electrical driven systems will fail after a complete generator failure due to a significant drop in voltage when the battery takes over.
No special considerations are necessary since the battery takes over the emergency electrical power supply without any restrictions.
Since the only remaining source of electrical power is the aircraft battery the consumption of electrical power is time-limited.
All AC-driven electrical circuits will fail since the battery only provides DC power.

variant.question: What should a flight crew do following the loss of all fuel indications?

options.text: Turn off fuel pumps for 10 min and then turn them back on.
Land as soon as possible and prepare for power off landing.
Open the cross-feed valve to make sure the aeroplane stays in balance.
Recycle the circuit breaker, if it's part of a procedure, and check if the system restarts.

variant.question:
When flying in heavy precipitation, a pilot experiences communication issues. There is an increase in background noise and the pilot struggles to hear ATC. The pilot has previously flown this route multiple times and, when the weather has been clear, this has never happened. Other aircrafts seem to hear ATC fine.   
 What is the most likely reason for the interference?

options.text: The aircraft has lost its earth point in its electrical system.
You are out of range from the ATC station.
The batteries in your headset needs to be replaced.
The aircraft have lost multiple static wicks.

variant.question: A modern computer makes use of different internal buses to…

options.text: send and receive analogue and digital data.
transfer address, data, and control signals.
separate the hardware from the software.
supply electrical power to different devices.

variant.question:
A complex aircraft has four independent AC generators, namely:

GEN 1 (ENG 1)   
 GEN 2 (ENG 2)   
 APU GEN   
 EMER GEN

How are the generators connected to a split bus system?

options.text: In parallel, with all 4 generators connected to the same part of the split bus bar. Power is then shared along the length of the split bus bar.
It varies depending on the type of generator installed.
With 2 or more generators connected in series, so that any increase in power demand can be met.
In parallel, with one generator at a time supplying individual parts of the split bus bar.

variant.question: What happens once the pilot has operated the IDG (Integrated Drive Generator) disconnect button?

options.text: An electrical supply system will be lost, but can be reset in-flight.
The disconnect switch can be used to re-connect the IDG in-flight, after sufficient time for cooling the generator.
A hydraulic supply system will be lost.
An electrical supply system will be lost.

variant.question: An aircraft has 4 engine driven generators and a split bus AC distribution system. Which of the following statements is true if no failures occur in flight.

options.text: Each pair of generators is connected to a common AC bus.
The AC buses are connected with bus-tie breakers.
All 4 generators are connected to a common AC bus.
Each generator is connected to its own dedicated AC bus bar.

variant.question: In a four-engine aircraft with a generator on each engine, how is the AC power usually distributed?

options.text: All four generators are connected in series for highest power generation.
The generators are connected in pairs to a common bus bar.
All four generators are connected to one bus bar.
Each generator feeds its dedicated bus bar.

variant.question: The flight crew must be notified if a large amount of lithium batteries are being carried in cargo compartments, as these batteries...

options.text: freeze at low temperatures, causing cracks in their metal casing.
have the potential to start an uncontrolled chain reaction when an individual cell is damaged.
explode when the cabin altitude is too high because of the differential pressure.
have potential to produce heat, requiring fire fighters to be present during loading and unloading.

variant.question:
Refer to figure.

In the event of the failure of both generators during flight, which contactors need to be closed to feed the AC 2 EMER BUS? 

(Note: all contactors not mentioned are assumed to remain open).

options.text: BAT1, DCTIE and INV.
BAT2, BAT TIE, B1 and INV.
BAT2, TRU and AC1.
BAT1, BAT TIE, B2 and INV.

variant.question: The frequency of the current provided by an alternator depends on..

options.text: the strength of the excitation current.
its phase balance.
its rotation speed.
its load.

variant.question: A bundle of electrical cables within the avionics bay, and in close proximity to one another, have been poorly insulated during installation. What is the most significant risk?

options.text: Frequent and/or incoherent tripping of circuit breakers (CBs).
Increased power consumption of the components’, as poorly insulated cables have an increased internal resistance.
Fire as a result of electrical arcing.
Radio communication interference.

variant.question: Modern Lithium batteries have high energy density cells. If these are exposed to mechanical or thermal abuse, this can result in strong...

options.text: magnetic fields, leading to compass errors.
induced voltages, leading to radio interference
electric fields, leading to arcing incidents.
electric currents, leading to a thermal runaway.
